text: hi everyone anthony fantano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time
for a review of the new disclosure album
energy this is the latest lp from the
brotherly uk dance music duo
disclosure this is their first studio
effort since 2015's caracal
which was a bit of a star-studded shift
for chart potential which
actually worked with huge features from
lord and miguel
and the weeknd this project climbed
higher on the billboard 200
than their debut album ever did pretty
sure getting in early on the sam smith
bandwagon
and cooking up another hit with them
helped as well now if you liked this
record you liked this record
personally i wasn't crazy about it i
thought many of the tracks saw the duo
watering down
their true blue and visceral house
rhythms for more of a pop appeal i guess
but the tracks disclosure's been
dropping over the past few years
i think have been signaling a move back
to basics
the ecstasy ep they dropped earlier this
year was nothing but
pure uncut disco-infused funky house
rhythms
i went into this album hoping for a
release that mostly embraced
those aesthetics and sounds and that's
kind of the case
there are plenty of high energy high
velocity house bangers on this thing
especially on the front end
watch your step this is an anthem
with agile bass and pounding dance beats
as well as some simple synth chords
the progressions throughout this track
are fantastic really keep the momentum
going but truly the selling point of
this song
is kalis her vocal feature which is a
little fuzzed out a little distorted
that's fine makes the vocals pop many of
the lines she is delivering call back to
a time when house was seeing its
commercial breakthrough in the 90s next
we get the even more exciting lavender
which features
up and coming hip house artist channel
trace given the musical influences
of disclosure and trace it's just a
match made in heaven and it sounds like
it
traces flirty and low-key vocals and
lyrics contrast nicely with the
cycling and stuttering hits of synths
punchy kicks and incredibly rotund
bouncy bass the track is a lot like the
opener in that it undergoes a similar
series of
breaks transitions builds and segues
there are also some great melodic vocal
lines that come through on the back end
that make for a nice change of pace
then there is the explosive my high with
slow tai
and amine the track honestly feels like
being
on almost a deadly amount of uppers
i'm sweating my heart's pounding and
meanwhile i'm in a club where all the
loud music and
in lights is uh making my my brain freak
out whoa
whoa whoa
this is a very visceral let me be
in my zone anthem amine has a lot of
very cool sticky vocal lines and
refrains which
contrast very nicely from slow ties
incredibly manic
and somewhat disorienting feature
his cracked expressive voice continues
to be
something else then there's also duha
mali mali featuring malian singer
fatumata diyawara
whose vocal soar over these driving
two-step
rhythms the vocals and the enveloping
airy walls of synthesizers just make
this track pure bliss
so yeah there are great tracks on this
record but there are a few duds in the
track list too
i would say there's the incredibly moody
who knew featuring mick jenkins
which does feature some rhythms and
progressions that i think are quite
admirable
but mick's voice is just too manipulated
too washed out to really connect with
kind of sucks the humanity
out of his voice in my opinion then
there's senepa with blick bessie who i
think gives the weakest vocal
performance on the entire lp
there's not a firm hold on many notes
during his performance plus i think the
forced hushed shivering somewhat eerie
delivery is just not working
the production does get a bit more
engaging on the back end of the track
but
not enough to swing me into loving it
while yeah there are some tracks that
i'm not as crazy about
in this track list really my biggest
issue with the record though
is that past the halfway point it begins
to lose
shape entirely there are some interlude
cuts that feature the
sort of hip-hop production that you
might catch on one of those
24-hour lo-fi hip-hop anime study beat
youtube channels
which are fine but aesthetically they
have little to nothing to do with the
rest of the album they don't segue
they're not complementary and why we
need these detours i don't know because
it's not like the material or the album
up until this point
is so challenging so arduous so
demanding of listeners that
we would need a break then after the
second interlude which comes not too
long after the first
the tracklist hits with two of its most
low-key cuts
and then ducks out there is birthday
featuring kalani and sid of the internet
fame which sees disclosure dipping a
little bit into
an r b and dance music blend mostly it's
a cute song with sweet vocal passages
and thoughtful lyrics about checking in
on an ex on their birthday
hitting them up saying hi not trying to
rekindle anything but just see if
there's some
maturity there and potentially feel out
the
i don't know the possibility of i
suppose some friendship post
relationship yes it's a pretty endearing
song and if it were on a colony album
i'd with it heavy
probably but on this record it feels so
out of place because it's not really
reinforced by anything else
in the track list then there's also
reverie featuring common which feels
more like a
short motivational interlude than a
proper finisher the track doesn't sound
terrible but i can't help but feel like
commons words as well as the
new agey synths and hand drums ring as
a little hollow during this
socio-political climate where there is
so
little hope to be found anywhere the
whole thing just sounds like a
commercial to me honestly so energy
while i do think some of my favorite
disclosure material does turn up on this
album
overall i found this thing to just be
too inconsistent
and unorganized to enjoy all the way
through
the brothers do pick some great features
and draw up some fantastic house bangers
but
it doesn't prevent the album from
feeling kind of thrown together
and cutting off abruptly at the very end
feeling a strong six
on this one transition have you given
this album a listen
did you love it did you hate it what
would you rate it you're the best you're
the best what should i review next
hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well
over here next to my head is another
video that you can check out hit that up
or the link to subscribe to
the channel anthony fantano music
disclosure of forever
